document.title: Setting up a Freshwater Aquarium
document.introduction: Fishkeeping is a hobby that is often overlooked. Chances are you (or someone you know) has owned fish before only to find them belly-up within the week. This first-time experience with keeping fish can be incredibly disheartening, especially considering the time, cost, and effort put into caring for these seemingly simple creatures. This guide is designed to help beginning fish keepers who are serious about starting an aquarium that has the potential to last for years.

topic.introduction: Keeping fish is not as cheap or easy as it may initially seem! In order to properly care for your species, an aquarium requires many types of products and equipment. Here's a standard list of what you will most likely need to begin your aquarium:

list.listItem: A properly sized, waterproof fish tank; this can be made of glass or acrylic Warning: Do NOT use enclosures meant for non-aquatic animals; they are not built to hold water and will break under pressure.
A properly sized stand for your tank Warning: Do NOT put a fish tank on something that is not labeled for fish tank use like a desk or table: water is incredibly heavy and can damage surfaces.
A filter; this can include one or more hang-on-back (HOB), canister, or sump filters Note: For freshwater, the filter should have a gph (gallons per hour) rating of at least 5 times your tank size.

One or more properly rated, temperature-adjustable heaters for your tank Note: Make sure the heater has between 2.5-5 watts of power per gallon of your tank (for a 50-gallon tank, this will be 250-500 watts)

1-2lbs of Substrate per gallon of your tank size for 1-2 inches of coverage for the bottom of the tank Note: Some species will prefer certain types of substrates over others. If there is a particular species you are interested in keeping, check to see if there are any special substrate needs for that species.
Note: Make sure your substrate is suitable for aquarium use as materials not suitable for aquariums may leech harmful contaminants into the water.
A suitable light Note: If you are planning on getting plants for your aquarium, make sure the light you purchase is suitable for your desired species of plant(s).
A bottle of water conditioner; this will be paramount for setting up your aquarium and future water changes so that you do not burn the gills of your inhabitants.

Decorations you (and your species) would like in the aquarium Decorations and other structures are important because open water can induce stress on many species. Decorations can also be used to break the line of sight in your aquarium, inhibiting aggression.
A bottle of aquarium bacteria starter; this will expedite the nitrogen cycling (or simply “cycling”) process of the aquarium.
Fish food; this will help the cycling process.
A water testing kit; make sure it has at least a pH, ammonia, nitrite, and nitrate test.

topic.introduction: Having a set plan is integral for the longevity and health of your freshwater aquarium. Following this plan will help you avoid common beginner mistakes when beginning your fishkeeping journey.

steps.step: Make a list of what species you would like to keep including fish, invertebrates, and plants.
Rank your desired species from highest priority to lowest priority.
Research the minimum tank size suitable for each species. Note: For a single small fish this should be no less than 5 gallons.

Learn about the temperament of each species to keep the stress of your fish at a minimum. Note: Each species has different behavior patterns; a species might have a behavior that is docile, moderate, or aggressive; a species may fare best in a group that schools (a same-species group with a tight swimming pattern), shoals (a same-species group that loosely swims together), or is independent; and a species may reside mostly at the top, middle, or bottom of a tank.
Know the ideal water parameters of each species Note: This will include optimal temperature, pH, and water hardness.
Take notes of what type of habitat each species resides in best; this will affect your choice of substrate (sand or gravel) and your aquarium layout (open water or dense vegetation).

Choose what size tank you want to have. Note: Smaller tanks are cheaper to set up and require fewer resources to maintain.
Note: Larger tanks can house more individuals and tend to be more chemically stable.
Decide where to set up your aquarium. Note: Avoiding direct sunlight, hard-to-reach spots, carpeting, and heavy-traffic areas will make regular maintenance easier.
Create a final draft of what species you are going to keep from what you have researched.

topic.introduction: Setting up your aquarium will require more than just filling a glass box with water! Follow these instructions to properly set up your tank and minimize the mess:

steps.step: Clear the area where you will be putting your fish tank and stand.
Follow the instructions for your stand and place or build it in your desired location.
Place the tank on top of the stand if you have not done so already.

Place whatever decorations you like inside the tank. Note: Doing this before you add your substrate will anchor the decorations and will keep the decorations from tipping over and potentially harming your species.

Rinse your substrate to get rid of any debris. You may do this by using a colander for gravel or by cutting two holes at the top of the bag for sand, using one hole to fill the bag with water and the other to filter out the debris. Note: Failing to do this will result in very cloudy water that will last for several weeks.
Use your rinsed substrate to cover the bottom of the tank by at least 1 inch.

Follow the manufacturers' instructions to set up whatever equipment you have for your tank, including the filter, heater, and light. To avoid damaging your equipment, do NOT plug them in or power them on yet.
Fill the tank with tap water
Turn on your equipment to ensure it works properly.
Follow the instructions of your water conditioner and add the recommended amount to your tank.

topic.introduction: You're not at the finish line yet! Nitrogen cycling (or “cycling”) your tank is the absolute most important part of ensuring a healthy environment for your species. If this step is skipped or not properly followed, you will lose most, if not all, of your species. In total, this process will last from one to six weeks.

steps.step: Optional: If you like, you may now add aquatic plants at any time. The plants may help in cycling the tank and should be able to handle the cycling process.
Follow the instructions on your fish tank bacteria starter to kickstart and possibly expedite this process.
Add some food to the fish tank every couple of days. This will feed the bacteria in your tank.
Follow the instructions on your testing kit and test for ammonia, nitrite, and nitrate every day.
Once ammonia and nitrite read 0 and nitrate reads above 0 on your water test kit, you're ready to add some species!

topic.introduction: At long last, you can finally add some fish! Like cycling, this process may also take some time as the water chemistry will have to adjust as you add your species of fish. Be sure to continuously test your water to ensure a comfortable home for your species during this process.

steps.step: Start by adding a group of your most timid species. This will inhibit your more aggressive species from bullying them as they have already “claimed” most of the tank's territory. Note: Do not add more than a quarter of your entire species plan at a time so that the nitrogen cycle can catch up with the load of whatever species you add to the tank.
After your ammonia, nitrite, and nitrate levels have stabilized once again, you may add more species, leaving your most aggressive species for last.
